properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, possibly higher near the Fundy coast. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: Western New Brunswick. Remarks: Rain will begin Monday morning over southwestern New Brunswick, then spread rapidly across the province in the afternoon. The rain is expected to become heavy at times Monday night before ending early Tuesday morning. Strong southerly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rainfall, resulting in rapid snowmelt. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-12T23:48:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T07:49:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2098808473.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain tonight and Monday and strong winds Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Rain is forecast to begin tonight north of Lake Ontario and will expand into Eastern Ontario by Monday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are expected. The rain will taper off from west to east Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Strong southwesterly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible. These strong winds will ease Monday night. These winds and rain are associated with a strong low pressure system that is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T01:00:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T09:01:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2809274134.2020

properties.Title: Update To Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Is Being Issued By La Plonge Reserve
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory issued for La Plonge. This advisory has been extended, and is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the La Plonge water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system developing over Colorado will intensify as it approaches James Bay early in the week. Snow will begin Monday afternoon then the storm will intensify during the evening. A total of 15 to 20 centimetres of snow, strong winds and significant blowing snow giving near zero visibilities are expected. Conditions will improve on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T00:07:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T08:08:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1418954852.2020
Area: LG Quatre - Laforge and Fontanges

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall on Monday, 25 to 35 millimetres expected A low from Colorado will affect Quebec early this week, giving rain, while several rivers are being monitored. Heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected Monday. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing snow to the area. Snow is expected to begin late tonight before becoming heavy Monday morning. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h are also likely resulting in blowing snow. Snow and local blowing snow will continue Monday before tapering to flurries Monday night. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm will be possible. Snowfall amounts remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snowfall accumulations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Northwest winds with gusts up to 80 km/h combined with falling snow will give reduced visibilities of less than 400 meters to Clyde River. Visibilities are expected to deteriorate later this morning. Winds will gradually diminish on Monday and conditions will improve. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T00:25:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T08:26:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1250391420.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain tonight into Monday and strong winds Monday afternoon. Rain or snow will begin this evening and then transition to heavy rain tonight. Rain will continue Monday before changing to flurries Monday afternoon or evening. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected. Strong westerly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon. Wind gusts of 70 to 90 km/h will be possible with the strongest winds expected along the shorelines of Lake Superior and Lake Huron. Winds will ease Monday night. These strong winds and rain are the result of a strong low pressure system forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T01:02:07-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant winter storm is expected Monday into Monday night. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing snow and blowing snow to the area. Snow is expected to begin Monday morning and quickly become heavy. Northerly winds gusting near 60 or 70 km/h are also likely resulting in widespread blowing snow. Snow and blowing snow will continue into Monday night before tapering to flurries on Tuesday. Total snowfall amounts in the 30 to 50 cm range will be possible. Exact snowfall amounts remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snowfall accumulations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T01:22:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T09:23:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0517479569.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow will continue today in Qikiqtarjuaq with a further 5 to 10 cm expected. Snow will be heaviest this morning but light snow will likely persist through Sunday night with no further significant accumulations occurring. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

Heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on the roads. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential significant snowfall and rainfall tonight into Monday. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing heavy rain and snow to the area. Snow will begin late this evening over areas towards Timmins while rain will begin over areas closer to Sudbury. The snow will change over to rain on Monday then change back to flurries Monday afternoon or evening. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm over northern areas and total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm over southern areas will be possible. Exact snowfall amounts and the position of the rain snow line remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snow and rainfall amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T01:18:45-00:00
